choices.E: GRANT CREATE TABLE, SELECT ON hr.employees TO manager;
choices.C: GRANT CREATE ANY SESSION, CREATE ANY TABLE TO manager;
choices.A: GRANT CREATE SEQUENCE TO manager, emp;
choices.D: GRANT SELECT, INSERT ON hr.employees TO manager WITH GRANT OPTION;
choices.B: GRANT CREATE TABLE, emp TO manager;

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
- A: Grants the CREATE SEQUENCE system privilege to both the manager and emp roles.
It is valid to specify multiple roles or users in a single GRANT statement.
- B: CREATE TABLE is a system privilege, and privileges can be granted to roles.
- C: CREATE ANY SESSION is not a valid privilege in Oracle. It should be CREATE SESSION instead
- D: This syntax is valid.
- E: CREATE TABLE is a system privilege, and SELECT is an object privilege.
System and object privileges cannot be granted in the same GRANT statement

Selected Answer: AB
can grant system and object privileges in same grant statement

This command grants the CREATE TABLE privilege and SELECT privilege on the HR.EMPLOYEES table to the MANAGER role. This is valid syntax, as it grants both a system privilege and an object privilege to a role.
 That's by A,E is correct

2. EMP is an existing role containing the CREATE TABLE privilege.
3. EMPLOYEES is an existing table in the HR schema.

questions.question_text: Which two statements will convert the string Hello World to ello world? (Choose two.)

choices.D: SELECT LOWER(TRIM(‘H’ FROM ‘Hello World’)) FROM DUAL;
choices.A: SELECT INITCAP(TRIM(‘H’ FROM ‘Hello World’)) FROM DUAL;

discussion.content:
Logic has to be higher to lower otherwise condition will not address 2nd row D is correct 

select last_name, hire_date,

Case
 When sysdate - to_yminterval ('20-0') >= hire_date then 'Older than 20 years Employees'
 When sysdate - to_yminterval ('10-0') >= hire_date then 'Older than 10 years Employees'
 When sysdate - to_yminterval ('5-0') >= hire_date then 'Older than 5 years Employees'
 Else 'New Employees'
END as "Employees Duration"
from emp
order by "Employees Duration" desc
;

Selected Answer: D
Correct answer is D
SELECT e.last_name, hire_date, sysdate, 
(CASE WHEN (sysdate -TO_YMINTERVAL('15-0')) >= hire_date THEN '15 years of service'
WHEN (sysdate -TO_YMINTERVAL('10-0')) >= hire_date THEN '10 years of service'
WHEN (sysdate - TO_YMINTERVAL('5-0')) >= hire_date THEN '5 years of service'
ELSE '<5 years of service' END) AS years 
FROM employees 
ORDER BY hire_date

comments.content:
It cannot be B 
TO_YMINTERVAL must be to the left of the operator of the comparation and must be used to deduct a date

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I think answer is B.

questions.question_text:
Examine the description of the EMPLOYEES table:

//IMG//


Examine these requirements:

1. Display the last name, date of hire and the number of years of service for each employee.
2. If the employee has been employed 5 or more years but less than 10, display “5+ years of service”.
3. If the employee has been employed 10 or more years but less than 15, display “10+ years of service”.
4. If the employee has been employed 15 or more years, display “15+ years of service”.
5. If none of these conditions matches, display “<5 years of service”.
6. Sort the results by the HIRE_DATE column.

Which statement satisfies all the requirements?

discussion.content:
B. Alter Table XYZ Read only
D. Alter Table XYZ Rename to ABC
F. ALTER TABLE employees ADD CONSTRAINT emp_pk PRIMARY KEY (employee_id);

E. You cant drop all columns from table with Drop. you can drop multiple.

choices.C: Lock a set of rows in a table.
choices.F: Enable or disable constraints on a table.
choices.B: Restrict all DML statements on a table.
choices.E: Drop all columns simultaneously from a table.

questions.question_text: Which three actions can you perform by using the ALTER TABLE command? (Choose three.)

choices.E: A BLOB stores unstructured binary data within the database.
choices.D: A CHAR column definition does not require the length to be specified.
choices.B: A VARCHAR2 blank-pads column values only in the data stored is non-numeric and contains no special characters.
choices.F: A BFILE stores unstructured binary data in operating system files.
choices.C: A VARCHAR2 column definition does not require the length to be specified.
choices.A: The default length for a CHAR column is always one character.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AEF
But based on the scheme ans, id D is correct , then A should be correct!

Yes, you can create a table in ORACLE without specifying the length in CHAR column.
D is right.
you can't create a table in ORACLE without specifying the length in CHAR column

If you do not specify a qualifier, the value of the NLS_LENGTH_SEMANTICS parameter of the session creating the column defines the length semantics, unless the table belongs to the schema SYS, in which case the default semantics is BYTE.

Selected Answer: DEF
DEF for me, 
CHAR default is 1 byte, 
we can use: CREATE TABLE tmp (col CHAR);

Selected Answer: AEF
Answer is A,E,F
